Families of elementary and middle school students will have an easier way to track and pay for school lunches this year. Students will continue to use their school IDs to pay for lunch. Families will load and refresh accounts through MySchoolBucks.

MySchoolBucks allows families to add funds by logging into PowerSchool or by downloading the MySchoolBucks app. Families will be able to monitor their student's purchases, check balances, and receive low-balance alerts. Balances from the previous system have all been rolled over to the new MySchoolBucks accounts.

Letters are being sent via U.S. mail to kindergarten through sixth-grade students with instructions and your personalized code for creating a PowerSchool account. Returning seventh- and eighth-grade families should already have a PowerSchool log on.

Learn more: https://bit.ly/39Ub4bH

The Glenbard Parent Series will be presenting a free talk with pediatrician Dr. Ken Ginsburg, who will discuss how to build resilience during challenging and turbulent times. The talk will be at 7 p.m. on Wednesday, June 17.
Ginsburg will share ideas for enhancing empathy and understanding, with simple takeaways that will strengthen emotional health in our children and ourselves.
Ginsburg is a pediatrician specializing in adolescent medicine and a professor of pediatrics at the University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine. His research has focused on helping young people develop solutions to social problems and teaching clinicians how to better serve them.
Dr. Ginsburg will speak for 35 minutes, and then answer questions sent in advance to Gilda Ross at gilda_ross@glenbard.org. Area superintendents will moderate the discussion.
More information about viewing the event is available here: http://www.glenbardgps.org/event/building-resilience-in-our-challenging-turbulent-times/

This week, the halls of Arbor View Elementary have been filled with kites as students learned about and celebrated the “Festival of Uttarayn”.
The festival is a celebration from Gujurat, India’s western-most state. The festival marks the day when winter turns to summer on the Indian calendar. The festival signals that the sun is back and harvest season is near.
Many Gujurat cities organize kite competitions between residents. Uttarayan is such a huge celebration that it has become a public holiday in the eastern and western parts of India.
This week, students made and decorated kites. They learned more about the festival from Arbor View students who celebrate the tradition. They even got to try flying some kites!

Watch this video to learn more about how Briar Glen physical education teacher Michael Casmer uses his basketball unit to develop skills well beyond dribbling and defense. Using the "sports-ed" model, Casmer's eight-week basketball unit has become one of the highlights of the year for students.

Students learn the basics of basketball, but they don't just play scrimmages. The students are also referees, scorekeepers, fans, and coaches. Casmer leads the students through lessons on how to run a practice and they learn how to call fouls and track rebounds. The students work on fair play and good sportsmanship.

Students played music at halftime of the championship game. They also created their own team logos and introduction videos using library software.

In the end, Casmer creates a unit that engages all students, builds leadership - and teaches basketball basics.

Video: https://youtu.be/-3gGrISHNLQ
